It's still a long time until it's affordable for a normal person to go into orbit. An atlas V launch costs currently about $100m, so even not counting the cost of the capsule and extra work required for a manned flight, it would be over $10m per seat in the CST-100. A falcon 9 launch currently costs about $60m and still they're projected launch price per crew dragon was $140m or $20m per seat. The CST-100 is likely to cost a lot more than that.

Well, giant single-use first stages full of expensive rocket fuel are more expensive in the long run through.

Rocket fuel is the cheapest part of the launch. You will always need a huge amount of energy to reach orbital speed. You will always need a damn heavy vehicle to carry that amount of energy. Adding a giant airplane into the equation doesn't make it cheaper. It makes it more complex, more dangerous, and more expensive.

And expendable rockets are made to be expendable, which makes them relatively cheap compared to an airplane.
